pr_title: [MOB-1896] allow token to be set with same email or userId

timeline.message: allow token to be set with same email or userId

timeline.author: Ayyanchira
Ayyanchira

timeline.message: add stricter checks for setting auth data

timeline.bodyText: we will need to set _email to new email
timeline.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: It's already the same by that point
replies.author: roninopf

replies.bodyText: Not when _email(current email) is null as stated in above comments. If null case is handled on top, else if part can be considered as just updating the authToken
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: This got really confusing to follow the flow for something so important, so I simplified it. The handling of null and setting info accurately should be right, now, if I haven't messed anything else up!
replies.author: roninopf

timeline.bodyText: This will skip execution if _email (current email) is null. The tests caught that.
timeline.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: Ah, because it should empty out authentication info if it's null.
replies.author: roninopf

timeline.bodyText: I think this still doesn't do what we want it to do.. We don't want to run logout/login if current email & userId are null, and the new email is also null.
timeline.author: vbabenkoru

timeline.bodyText: Since we don't check for nullity of _email here, if we pass an non-null email when the current _email is null, it will throw an exception.
timeline.author: vbabenkoru

timeline.message: add token cases after reverting to existing flow

timeline.bodyText:
if we return here,
we won't perform setEmail for where developer doesnt want to implement authToken at all. authToken and _authToken being null should still allow setEmail operation
timeline.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: Hmm, this is only for when the previous and new emails are the same. Nothing should happen, right? That was the previous behavior too. It just used to return.
replies.author: roninopf

replies.bodyText: oh yes.. looks good here.
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: I strongly feel we should have multiple tests written for it first. Kind of -> if those pass, all good
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: I'll see if I can fit tests into this PR.
replies.author: roninopf

timeline.bodyText: What do we need this for?
timeline.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: Oh! I suggested that in case we need to check authToken within our IterableAPI classes internally. Could be useful in test. And possibly in RN too (later).
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: Yeah, it was only to let the tests verify the authentication token directly. Otherwise the tests had no (easy) way to check them.
replies.author: roninopf

replies.bodyText: Hmm, interesting, I didn't know protected was accessible from tests.. I've always used package-private (no modifier) for this.
replies.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText:
"Protected data member and method are only accessible by the classes of the same package and the subclasses present in any package."
TIL! I thought they were only accessible by the subclasses.
replies.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: Oh!!! When I read package-private above, I realized thats I wanted to tell before!😅 But yeah strange that protected worked too
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: However in this case we don't have subclasses of IterableApi, so it would also work with package-private. Let me take a look at how getEmail/getUserId are declared..
replies.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: They're package-private.. I think next to them would also be a better place for it. @roninopf Could you remove protected keyword and move this method right below getUserId() in "Package-Protected Functions" group?
replies.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: roninopf

replies.bodyText: Is it protected causing the failure in travis?
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: @Ayyanchira Oh, right. Let's make it package-private to make it visible to tests.
replies.author: vbabenkoru

timeline.bodyText:
Since these tests aren't testing persistence, I think these shouldn't have *Persistence suffixes.
The tests checking persistence create a new instance of IterableApi to make sure it doesn't have values in memory and loads them from disk.
timeline.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: Will change the suffix
replies.author: roninopf

replies.bodyText: Renamed to *Status. There might be something better? But at least now it's not implying disk data.
replies.author: roninopf

timeline.message: split authentication tests to separate file

timeline.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: It's supposed to represent the status of the authentication data; I couldn't think of a good suffix that didn't make it more confusing, but I wanted to at least evade *Persistence.
replies.author: roninopf

replies.bodyText:
Just plain
testSetEmailWithToken
testSetEmailEmptyToken
testSetEmailWithNullToken
testSetNullEmailWithToken
kind of names would also work
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText: I think it won't lose anything without the suffix.. testSetEmailWithToken makes sense.
replies.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: Okay! I'll just drop it. I think you're right.
replies.author: roninopf

timeline.message: add userId logout test, make them more rigorous
set auth token accessor to package-protected
set authentication functions to package private
